result.execSummary:
This case has not been concluded. Unless a judgment of conviction is entered, the defendant is presumed innocent of all charges.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

to Branch 7

01:46 PM, cases 21CF2649 and 22CF401 addressed together.  Attorney Jake Idlas appeared on behalf of Paul M Fredrickson in court on behalf of defendant.  Rebekah M Rennicke appeared for the State of Wisconsin.  Hearing was set up for waiver of preliminary hearing, Zoom was set up for 1:30, as of 1:48, no show.  State is requesting a bench warrant be entered.  Atty. Idlas: asking that bench warrant be held off until, he has received a phone call from his mother, having issues with Zoom.  Court is going to call him.   Mr. Hickman has appeared by video means.    Defendant advised of right to and waived Preliminary Hearing (Preliminary Hearing Waiver signed); Court accepted waiver of Preliminary Hearing and ordered case bound over.
for telephonic appearance for 5-6-22 hearing

Cases 21CF2649,22CF401 addressed together.  Defendant in court with Attorney Devonte Windham on behalf of Attorney Paul M Fredrickson.  Rebekah M Rennicke appeared for the State of Wisconsin.  Court speaks to report, Atty. Windham, does agree with report.  CT: has colloquy with Mr. Hickman, is in agreement with findings.  ADA Rennicke: in agreement with report and asking that the court find Mr. Hickman competent.  Court adopts findings of competency report and does find Mr. Hickman competent.  Court finds date and time to set preliminary hearings.
Preliminary hearing on May 6, 2022 at 01:30 pm.
